importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the start of the Paris Climate Agreement, which shifted global warming projections from a catastrophic 4°C to a more moderate 2.6°C by 2100, altering the expected number of superhot days.
The study estimates that since 2015, the world has already added 11 average superhot days per year, indicating a measurable, ongoing climate impact.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The study projects that by 2100, the Earth will have 57 additional superhot days annually due to climate change, even under current mitigation efforts.
The period since the Paris Climate Agreement has seen a significant reduction in projected warming, but still a substantial increase in dangerous heat days.

keyTakeAways: The world will experience an additional 57 superhot days per year by 2100 due to climate change, even under current Paris Agreement commitments.
The increase in superhot days is significantly lower than the worst-case scenario (114 days) that would have occurred without climate action.
Since 2015, the world has already added 11 average superhot days per year.
Small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa will face the largest increases in dangerous heat days, despite contributing only 1% of global carbon emissions.
The top carbon-emitting countries (U.S., China, India) will face only 23–30 extra superhot days, despite being responsible for 42% of global CO2 emissions.
The disparity in heat exposure highlights deep global inequality in climate impacts, potentially fueling geopolitical instability.
Experts stress that the current warming trajectory still poses a disastrous future for billions of people, with tens of thousands or millions exposed to deadly heatwaves annually.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This entity conducted the study that calculates the increase in superhot days due to climate change, providing scientific attribution of extreme weather to global warming.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Climate Central is a key collaborator in the study, contributing to the analysis of climate impacts and the attribution of heat extremes to climate change.

namedEntities.name: Paris Climate Agreement
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international treaty adopted in 2015 to limit global warming to well below 2°C.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Paris Agreement is central to the article, as it changed the trajectory of global warming from 4°C to 2.6°C, thereby reducing—but not eliminating—the number of superhot days.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that even under current Paris Agreement commitments, the world will still experience an additional 57 superhot days annually by 2100—nearly two months of dangerous heat. This represents a significant improvement over the worst-case scenario of 114 days, but still indicates a severe and growing threat. The study reveals a stark inequality in climate impacts: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face massive increases in heat days (up to 149 per year), despite contributing only 1% of global emissions. In contrast, top emitters such as the U.S., China, and India face only 23–30 extra days. Experts warn that this disparity reflects a profound injustice and could fuel geopolitical instability, while emphasizing that tens of thousands or millions of people will still face deadly heatwaves each year.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
